Exaggerate: The claim may be exaggerating the percentage of people crossing the border who are "non-impactable" by stating that "more than half" fall into this category. This may not be an accurate representation of the actual numbers.
Lack enough support: The claim does not provide sufficient evidence or data to support the statement that "more than half the people crossing the border are non-impactable." It is unclear where this information is derived from.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that a border wall would have no impact on the "non-impactable" individuals crossing the border. This assumption may not be entirely accurate as the effectiveness of a border wall in deterring or handling different types of border crossers is a complex issue.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations or factors that contribute to the number of "non-impactable" individuals crossing the border, such as the root causes of migration or the effectiveness of alternative border security measures.
